The OCB Authenticated-Encryption Algorithm The OCB Authenticated-Encryption Algorithm
draft-irtf-cfrg-ocb-07 draft-irtf-cfrg-ocb-07
Abstract Abstract
This document specifies OCB, a shared-key blockcipher-based This document specifies OCB, a shared-key blockcipher-based
encryption scheme that provides confidentiality and authenticity for encryption scheme that provides confidentiality and authenticity for
plaintexts and authenticity for associated data. This document is a plaintexts and authenticity for associated data. This document is a
product of the Crypto Forum Research Group (CFRG). product of the Crypto Forum Research Group (CFRG).

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
Schemes for authenticated encryption (AE) simultaneously provide for Schemes for authenticated encryption (AE) simultaneously provide for
confidentiality and authentication. While this goal would confidentiality and authentication. While this goal would
traditionally be achieved by melding separate encryption and traditionally be achieved by melding separate encryption and
authentication mechanisms, each using its own key, integrated AE authentication mechanisms, each using its own key, integrated AE
schemes intertwine what is needed for confidentiality and what is schemes intertwine what is needed for confidentiality and what is
needed for authenticity. By conceptualizing AE as a single needed for authenticity. By conceptualizing AE as a single
cryptographic goal, AE schemes are less likely to be misused than cryptographic goal, AE schemes are less likely to be misused than

OCB encryption protects the confidentiality of P and the authenticity OCB encryption protects the confidentiality of P and the authenticity
of A, N, and P. It does this using, on average, about a + m + 1.02 of A, N, and P. It does this using, on average, about a + m + 1.02
blockcipher calls, where a is the blocklength of A and m is the blockcipher calls, where a is the blocklength of A and m is the
blocklength of P and the nonce N is implemented as a counter (if N is blocklength of P and the nonce N is implemented as a counter (if N is

cost to having A authenticated on subsequent encryptions, and the cost to having A authenticated on subsequent encryptions, and the
mode will average m + 1.02 blockcipher calls. OCB requires a single mode will average m + 1.02 blockcipher calls. OCB requires a single
key K for the underlying blockcipher, and all blockcipher calls are key K for the underlying blockcipher, and all blockcipher calls are
keyed by K. OCB is online. In particular, one need not know the keyed by K. OCB is online. In particular, one need not know the
length of A or P to proceed with encryption, nor need one know the length of A or P to proceed with encryption, nor need one know the
length of A or C to proceed with decryption. OCB is parallelizable: length of A or C to proceed with decryption. OCB is parallelizable:
the bulk of its blockcipher calls can be performed simultaneously. the bulk of its blockcipher calls can be performed simultaneously.
Computational work beyond blockcipher calls consists of a small and Computational work beyond blockcipher calls consists of a small and
fixed number of logical operations per call. OCB enjoys provable fixed number of logical operations per call. OCB enjoys provable
security: the mode of operation is secure assuming that the security: the mode of operation is secure assuming that the
underlying blockcipher is secure. As with most modes of operation, underlying blockcipher is secure. As with most modes of operation,
security degrades as the number of blocks processed gets large (see security degrades as the number of blocks processed gets large (see
Section 5 for details). Section 5 for details).

The version of OCB defined in this document is a refinement of two The version of OCB defined in this document is a refinement of two
prior schemes. The original OCB version was published in 2001 [OCB1] prior schemes. The original OCB version was published in 2001 [OCB1]
and was listed as an optional component in IEEE 802.11i. A second and was listed as an optional component in IEEE 802.11i. A second
version was published in 2004 [OCB2] and is specified in ISO 19772. version was published in 2004 [OCB2] and is specified in ISO 19772.
The scheme described here is called OCB3 in the 2011 paper describing The scheme described here is called OCB3 in the 2011 paper describing
the mode [OCB3]; it shall be referred to simply as OCB throughout the mode [OCB3]; it shall be referred to simply as OCB throughout
this document. The only difference between the algorithm of this RFC this document. The only difference between the algorithm of this RFC
and that of the [OCB3] paper is that the tag length is now encoded and that of the [OCB3] paper is that the tag length is now encoded
into the internally formatted nonce. See [OCB3] for complete into the internally formatted nonce. See [OCB3] for complete
references, timing information, and a discussion of the differences references, timing information, and a discussion of the differences
between the algorithms. between the algorithms.

bitlen(S) The length of string S in bits (eg, bitlen(101) == 3). bitlen(S) The length of string S in bits (eg, bitlen(101) == 3).
zeros(n) The string made of n zero-bits. zeros(n) The string made of n zero-bits.
ntz(n) The number of trailing zero bits in the base-2 ntz(n) The number of trailing zero bits in the base-2
representation of the positive integer n. More representation of the positive integer n. More
formally, ntz(n) is the largest integer x for which 2^x formally, ntz(n) is the largest integer x for which 2^x
divides n. divides n.
S xor T The string that is the bitwise exclusive-or of S and T. S xor T The string that is the bitwise exclusive-or of S and T.
Strings S and T will always have the same length. Strings S and T will always have the same length.

S is 011 then S[1] == 0, S[2] == 1, S[3] == 1). S is 011 then S[1] == 0, S[2] == 1, S[3] == 1).

3. OCB Global Parameters 3. OCB Global Parameters
To be complete, the algorithms in this document require specification To be complete, the algorithms in this document require specification
of two global parameters: a blockcipher operating on 128-bit blocks of two global parameters: a blockcipher operating on 128-bit blocks
and the length of authentication tags in use. and the length of authentication tags in use.
Specifying a blockcipher implicitly defines the following symbols. Specifying a blockcipher implicitly defines the following symbols.
KEYLEN The blockcipher's key length, in bits. KEYLEN The blockcipher's key length, in bits.
